instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> powers off as soon as J3501 cable is connected.
threads.message: Any idea where to start? power lines are all fine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> powers off as soon as J3501 cable is connected.
threads.message: You're not supposed to plug that in with the board on. Does the board power on with it connected? If not first try a know good cable and airport card.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> powers off as soon as J3501 cable is connected.
threads.message: The board turns on with it connected and after 10 seconds turns off

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> powers off as soon as J3501 cable is connected.
threads.message: Did you try a known good cable and airport?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> powers off as soon as J3501 cable is connected.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> powers off as soon as J3501 cable is connected.
threads.message: Does the screen come on before the board shuts off? Did you change the cable and airport card both at the same time?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> powers off as soon as J3501 cable is connected.
threads.message: Yes changed both, the screen comes on before it turns off

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> powers off as soon as J3501 cable is connected.
threads.message: Remove <CHIP>U3540</CHIP> and see if stays on.
